modules.description: Processes byte streams from various sources such as strings, file descriptors, and compressed data. Supports reading, seeking, and wrapping operations to handle input efficiently. Used to decode binary formats, read from network sockets, and process compressed files.

Writes bytes to various output destinations such as buffers, output channels, and file descriptors. Supports operations like writing single bytes, byte sequences, and formatted strings. Used to direct program output to files, network sockets, or in-memory buffers.

Establishes a TCP server listening on a specified address, spawning a new fiber for each connection using Iostreams for bidirectional communication. Operates with Unix.sockaddr and Lwt_io.server types to manage network connections. Used to handle concurrent client interactions, such as processing HTTP requests or real-time data streams.

Establishes a TCP connection to a specified address and executes a provided function with input and output streams. Operates on Unix.sockaddr and Iostream types to handle network communication. Used for sending and receiving data over a persistent TCP session in asynchronous code.

Provides asynchronous reading from and writing to file descriptors using Lwt's event loop. Operates on Unix file descriptors and byte buffers, enabling non-blocking I/O operations. Supports efficient data transfer in network or file-based applications requiring concurrency.

Reads and writes byte streams from diverse sources and destinations, enabling efficient handling of binary data, network communication, and compressed files. Provides data types for input and output channels, along with operations to read, write, seek, and wrap byte sequences. Examples include decoding binary files, sending data over sockets, and writing formatted output to buffers. Supports both low-level byte manipulation and high-level structured data processing.

Establishes TCP servers and clients using Lwt for asynchronous networking, with bidirectional communication via Iostreams. Processes incoming connections in separate fibers, enabling concurrent handling of multiple clients, and supports sending and receiving data over persistent sessions. Accepts Unix.sockaddr for address configuration and provides functions to manage input and output streams. Can be used to build real-time chat servers, HTTP handlers, or data relay systems.

Provides functions for spawning and managing concurrent tasks, including blocking and non-blocking I/O operations. Works with threads, file descriptors, and asynchronous event loops. Enables building simple concurrent applications like network servers or parallel data processing pipelines.

Combines Fuseau fibers with Lwt's event loop to enable asynchronous I/O and networking. Provides operations for non-blocking file descriptor access, byte stream manipulation, and TCP communication, using Unix file descriptors, byte buffers, and Iostreams. Enables efficient data transfer, binary processing, and concurrent network services. Examples include reading from sockets, writing compressed files, and handling multiple TCP clients simultaneously.
